markdownRemark.html:
In business scenarios, we often use Form for some data collection tasks. In this chapter, we will implement a simple Form to collect data and communicate with the back-end for transmission.

First, let's take a look at what Form we need to implement in this chapter:

Form demo form Bind the data source.

As can be seen from the above content, there are fields that must be input, and there are also fields that require special verification, such as mobile phone numbers, as well as fields with suffixes or prefixes.

Next, we start with the construction of the DataSet and build the simplest Form step by step.

Build DataSet

First, we need to construct a simple DataSet to collect data for this Form:

// DataSet.js
const FormDataSet = {
    // When the DataSet does not interact with the backend, it automatically creates a new piece of data, which is more common in the form scenario
    autoCreate: true,
    fields: [
        // Here is an agreement with the backend, the fields used when uploading
        {name:'phone', type:'string', label:'phone number' },
        {name:'password', type:'string', label:'password' },
        {name:'confirmPassword', type:'string', label:'Confirm password' },
        {name:'age', type:'number', label:'age' },
        {name:'sex', type:'string', label:'sex' },
        {name:'language', type:'string', label:'language' },
        {name:'email', type:'string', label:'mailbox' },
        {name:'homePage', type:'string', label:'personal homepage' },
        {name:'birth', type:'date', label:'birthday' },
    ],
    transport: {
        // The method that the DataSet will call when it is created
        // Find any url, you can replace it yourself
        // create / read / update / destroy can be replaced with functions in equal amounts. create involves uploading newly created data, so data is needed
        create: ({ data, params, dataSet }) => {
            console.log('data', data,  'params', params, ' dataSet.toJSONData()', dataSet.toJSONData());
            return ({
                // url: 'v1/projects/${projectId}',
                // method: 'post',
                // data,
            })
        }
    },
    events: {
        load: ({ dataSet }) => {
            console.log('Loading complete', dataSet)
        }
    }
};
export default FormDataSet;

Next, let's take a look at the Form that needs to be implemented. Here we can find that there are several points to note:

  1. Gender and language are multi-select boxes/drop-down boxes, and there are two ways to write these items. Here we introduce the way to write bound data sources.
  2. The phone number itself has a special check, we need to configure the field in the field accordingly

Let’s look at the first question first.

Bind the data source to achieve multiple selection / drop-down selection

The main advantage of binding the data source to implement multiple selection/drop-down is that if these two fields need to obtain multiple-selection/drop-down values from the backend in the future, we do not need to modify the rendering code too much. In fact, we only need to create two DataSets for these two drop-down boxes.

First, create two new DataSet construct objects for gender and language, respectively, called sexOptionDataSet and languageOptionDataSet.

// sexOptionDataSet.js
const sexOptionDataSet = {
     fields: [
         // The field configuration here is actually virtual according to our own needs
         // In fact, if you read the value from the backend, you still have to write it according to the backend specification
         {name:'text', type:'string' },
         {name:'value', type:'string' },
     ],
     // Because our needs are relatively simple, we can directly use data to generate local fake data
     data: [{
         text:'Male',
         value:'male',
     }, {
         text:'Female',
         value:'female',
     }],
};
export default sexOptionDataSet;
// languageOptionDataSet.js
// The same reason as the construction object above
const languageOptionDataSet = {
     fields: [
         {name:'text', type:'string' },
         {name:'value', type:'string' },
     ],
     data: [{
         text:'Simplified Chinese',
         value:'zh-cn',
     }, {
         text:'English (United States)',
         value:'en-us',
     }, {
         text:'japanese',
         value:'ja-jp',
     }],
};
export default languageOptionDataSet;

Then, we modify the previously generated DataSet, pass in the two newly created optionDataSets and build them.

// DataSet.js
import { DataSet } from 'choerodon-ui/pro';
import SexOptionDataSet from './sexOptionDataSet';
import LanguageOptionDataSet from './languageOptionDataSet';
const sexOptionDataSet = new DataSet(SexOptionDataSet);
const languageOptionDataSet = new DataSet(LanguageOptionDataSet);

const FormDataSet = {
    autoCreate: true,
    fields: [
        { name: 'phone', type: 'string', label: '手机号' },
        { name: 'password', type: 'string', label: '密码' },
        { name: 'confirmPassword', type: 'string', label: '确认密码' },
        { name: 'age', type: 'number', label: '年龄' },
         // textField refers to the field designated to display the option name in the lower-level options, here we have set it as text
         // Similarly, valueField refers to the value specified in the lower-level options for transmission to the backend, here we specify it as value
        { name: 'sex', type: 'string', label: '性别', textField: 'text', valueField: 'value', options: sexOptionDataSet },
        { name: 'language', type: 'string', label: '语言', textField: 'text', valueField: 'value', options: languageOptionDataSet },
        { name: 'email', type: 'string', label: '邮箱' },
        { name: 'homePage', type: 'string', label: '个人主页' },
        { name: 'birth', type: 'date', label: '生日' },
    ],
    transport: {
        create: ({ data, params, dataSet }) => {
            console.log('data', data,  'params', params, ' dataSet.toJSONData()', dataSet.toJSONData());
            return ({
                // url: 'v1/projects/${projectId}',
                // method: 'post',
                // data,
            })
        }
    },
    events: {
        load: ({ dataSet }) => {
            console.log('load', dataSet)
        }
    }
};
export default FormDataSet;

Next, the initial preparations for the Form are complete, and we can start writing the code for the rendering layer. Form requires more components, such as NumberField for numeric input, DatePicker for date selection, and so on. We will introduce them one by one.

// Table.jsx
import React from 'react';
import FormDS from './DataSet';
import {
  DataSet,
  Form,
  TextField,
  Password,
  NumberField,
  EmailField,
  UrlField,
  DatePicker,
  Select,
  SelectBox,
  Button,
  Menu,
  Dropdown,
  Icon,
} from 'choerodon-ui/pro';

class MyForm extends React.Component {
    constructor(props) {
        super(props);
        this.formDataSet = new DataSet(FormDS);
    }   
     // It should be noted here that Form can receive one of the two attributes of record and dataSet.
     // After the dataSet attribute is passed in, the Form will point to the ds.current of the DataSet by default, and the default is the first
     // If you need to specify a piece of data in the dataSet, please use the record attribute
    render() {
        return (
            <Form dataSet={this.formDataSet}>
                <TextField name="phone" />
                <Password name="password" />
                <Password name="confirmPassword" />
                <NumberField name="age" />
                <SelectBox name="sex" />
                <Select name="language" />
                <EmailField name="email" />
                <UrlField name="homePage" />
                <DatePicker name="birth" />
                <div>
                    <Button type="submit">submit</Button>
                    <Button type="reset" style={{ marginRight: 8 }}>reset</Button>
                </div>
            </Form>
        )
    }
}
export default MyForm;

As you can see, the form implemented with DataSet feels very refreshing overall, and the logic responsible for data interaction is hidden in the DataSet. Next, let's deal with the second question, how to verify the field.

Check the field

There are three fields in field, validator, pattern and required. These three fields can help us to verify the fields.

First look at the verification of the mobile phone number. The verification of the mobile number is very easy to find. You can find it after a little search on the Internet. We put it in the pattern.

Secondly, each field has a mandatory check, so we need to add required = true to each field.

Finally, confirm that the password field needs to be compared with the password field, so we need to use the validator field to define a custom function to customize the verification.

A little modification of our previous DataSet:

// DataSet.js
import {DataSet} from'choerodon-ui/pro';
import SexOptionDataSet from'./sexOptionDataSet';
import LanguageOptionDataSet from'./languageOptionDataSet';
const sexOptionDataSet = new DataSet(SexOptionDataSet);
const languageOptionDataSet = new DataSet(LanguageOptionDataSet);

const FormDataSet = {
    autoCreate: true,
    fields: [
        {name:'phone', type:'string', label:'phone number', pattern: '1[0-9]{10}', required: true },
        {name:'password', type:'string', label:'password', required: true },
        {name:'confirmPassword', type:'string', label:'Confirm password', required: true, validator: (value, name, record) => {
            // This place can return more than Boolean type and string type, you can also write a custom style of html tag yourself, such as changing the font color to blue
            if (value !== record.get('password')) {
                return'The passwords you entered two times are inconsistent, please re-enter';
            }
            return true;
        } },
        {name:'age', type:'number', label:'age', required: true },
        {name:'sex', type:'string', label:'gender', textField:'text', valueField:'value', options: sexOptionDataSet, required: true },
        {name:'language', type:'string', label:'language', textField:'text', valueField:'value', options: languageOptionDataSet, required: true },
        {name:'email', type:'string', label:'mailbox', required: true },
        {name:'homePage', type:'string', label:'personal homepage', required: true },
        {name:'birth', type:'date', label:'birthday', required: true },
    ],
    transport: {
        create: ({ data, params, dataSet }) => {
            console.log(data+" ", params+" ", dataSet.toJSONData());
            return ({
                // url: 'v1/projects/${projectId}',
                // method: 'post',
                // data,
            })
        }
    },
    events: {
        load: ({ dataSet }) => {
            console.log('Loading complete', dataSet)
        }
    }
};
export default FormDataSet;

In this way, we have completed the simplest form. In the next chapter, we will explain how to use the DataSet to construct a simple tree.

frontmatter.title: 开发体验 —— 最简 Table 实现
